Subjective: Right-sided low back pain for 1.5 weeks, progressively worsening. Pain radiates down posterior/lateral right thigh and lower leg to the foot. Associated tingling and dull sensation on the outside of the right lower leg. Pain is constant, all day. Impact: Unable to sleep ('awake for nights'), stopped working at supermarket (involves heavy lifting). Meds: Paracetamol and Ibuprofen at maximum doses with no relief. Pertinent Negatives: Subjectively feels strength is normal. No loss of bowel or bladder control. Normal sensation in saddle area ('riding breeches area'). ICE: Concerned about pain; wants to get rid of it. Asks about CT/MRI and surgery, referencing a neighbor's experience.
Objective: General: Appears in pain, especially when moving onto the examination bench. Back: No visible abnormalities. No vertebral tenderness on palpation. Pain elicited on palpation over right gluteal area. Neurological/Musculoskeletal: Sensation: Decreased/dull sensation on the right leg/foot compared to the left. Motor: Strength 5/5 and symmetrical in bilateral lower extremities. Reflexes: Normal and symmetrical. Special Tests: Straight leg raise test is positive on the right, negative on the left.
Assessment: Lumbosacral radicular syndrome, secondary to suspected disc herniation (hernia). No signs of cauda equina syndrome.
Plan: 1. Explanation: Provided education on nerve compression from a herniated disc. 2. Medication: Start Pregabalin for neuropathic pain, with slow dose titration. 3. Advice: Warned about side effects and driving restrictions (no driving for 1 week after starting or increasing dose). Recommended physiotherapy for exercises. 4. Imaging/Surgery: Explained scans and surgery are not indicated at this time; conservative management is the first-line approach. 5. Safety Netting: Contact GP/out-of-hours service immediately for worsening symptoms, specifically loss of sensation in saddle area, loss of bowel/bladder control, or significant leg weakness. 6. Follow-up: Telephone appointment in 1 week to review pain control.
